Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of a New Surgical Drape on Cutaneous Heat Loss

Trial_Design.evidence: In a randomised controlled trial, 8 volunteers were recruited.

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included healthy adults, and the study was conducted in a controlled laboratory setting.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to be covered with either the new drape or two conventional drapes (Large Surgical Drape and Medline Proxima) in a crossover design.

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the effectiveness of a new moisture-impervious surgical drape in reducing evaporative heat loss compared to conventional drapes.

Method_Outcome.evidence: Cutaneous heat loss and skin-surface temperatures were measured using 15 area-weighted thermal flux transducers over a 40-minute period following a 20-minute control period.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Analysed.evidence: All 8 participants completed the study, and data were analysed per-protocol.

Result_Outcome.evidence: Baseline heat loss under dry conditions was 82±14 watts (W), decreasing by 30% with any drape (P<0.001).
